title: 110_hr6372
content: The Act is titled the "Commodity Futures Restoration Act" and extends the jurisdiction of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to derivatives involving energy commodities. The Commodity Exchange Act is amended to remove energy commodities from the definition of exempt commodities. The term "energy commodity" is defined to include coal, crude oil, gasoline, diesel fuel, heating oil, propane, electricity, natural gas, and other non-excluded commodities. The Commodity Exchange Act is amended to remove energy commodities from the definition of exempt commodities, including coal, crude oil, gasoline, diesel fuel, heating oil, propane, electricity, natural gas, and other non-excluded commodities. The Act now allows the Commission to determine what constitutes an energy commodity used as a source of energy. The Foreign Board of Trade exception for certain futures transactions is being narrowed under Section 3. Section 4 of the Commodity Exchange Act is amended to specify that a board of trade, exchange, or market will not be considered foreign if it has a U.S. affiliate, trades commodity futures in the U.S., or executes significant price discovery contracts. An entity is deemed an affiliate if it owns 50% or more of the board of trade. The Commodity Exchange Act is amended to clarify that a board of trade, exchange, or market is not considered foreign if it has a U.S. affiliate, trades commodity futures in the U.S., or executes significant price discovery contracts. An entity is deemed an affiliate if it owns 50% or more of the board of trade. SEC. 4 extends the jurisdiction of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to swaps involving an energy commodity. It eliminates the exemption for excluded swap transactions involving an energy commodity and includes swaps in determining compliance with position and transaction limits. SEC. 5 requires a progress report. Within 90 days of this Act's effective date, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission must report to the House and Senate Agriculture Committees on the progress of implementing amendments, including any exemptions granted and reasons for not establishing position limits on energy commodity contracts. The report should also cover margin requirements for transactions in these contracts. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission must report on implementing amendments and exemptions within 90 days of the Act's effective date, including margin requirements for transactions in energy commodity contracts. Definitions in the report align with the Commodity Exchange Act. The Act does not affect the authority of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission or the Federal Trade Commission to carry out their responsibilities. The Act and its amendments will take effect 6 months after enactment.
